titleStmt.title: A collation of Mark at selected variation units from the United Bible Societies Greek New Testament, 5th Edition, using the collation of the Editio Critica Maior

availability.p: This is an open access work licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license.

interp.p: The current reading is absolutely more likely than the linked reading.
The current reading is strongly more likely than the linked reading.
The current reading is more likely than the linked reading.
The current reading is slightly more likely than the linked reading.
The current reading and the linked reading are equally likely.
Clarification of the text in terms of grammar, style, or theology.

Aural confusion concerning letters or dipthongs that came to have the same sound in later Greek, including various itacisms (i.e., interchanges between ι, ει, η, οι, and υ), \textgreek{αι}-\textgreek{ε} interchanges, ο-ω interchanges, interchanges between similar-sounding consonants (e.g., β-υ after certain vowels and π-φ) and other less common interchanges (e.g., vowel sounds that might be confused if spoken quickly).
Linguistic confusion concerning rules of Greek grammar.
Constructiones ad sensum that reflect changes in grammatical rules over time also fall under this rubric.

Visual error, such as paleographic confusion of similar letters, haplography, dittography and other repetitions of nearby letters, and other skips of the eye resulting in small omissions. Rarer situations, like duplication or omission of letters related to the presence or absence of an ornamental capital at the start of a line, also fall under this rubric.
Harmonization, either to a parallel passage or to the near context.
The text is brought into conformity with the Byzantine text.
